abstract: A British court ruling on the pension obligations of Nortel Networks and Lehman Brothers shows the flaws in a nation-by-nation approach to resolving insolvencies.
snippet: A British court ruling on the pension obligations of Nortel Networks and Lehman Brothers shows the flaws in a nation-by-nation approach to resolving insolvencies.
lead_paragraph: In the context of financial institutions, it is widely understood that the nation-by-nation approach to dealing with failing banks through laws like the Orderly Liquidation Authority of Title II of the Dodd-Frank Act really does not work. There is no such thing as a purely domestic "too big to fail" financial institution.

headline.main: The Conflict Between Global Companies and Local Laws
